head.title: Saint-Exupery, at Sea and in the Stars . . .

hedline.hl1: Saint-Exupery, at Sea and in the Stars . . .

block.p: Your article about the legendary writer Antoine de Saint-Exupery (Arts pages, June 7) no doubt struck a chord among the many readers for whom ''The Little Prince'' remains a sweet childhood memory.

Your article about the legendary writer Antoine de Saint-Exupery (Arts pages, June 7) no doubt struck a chord among the many readers for whom ''The Little Prince'' remains a sweet childhood memory.
What a mystical touch to learn that on the eve of the centenary of his birth, the military plane in which he disappeared in 1944 may have just been found on the floor of the Mediterranean.

But what the article left out is equally dramatic: in the course of the underwater search for his downed P-38 reconnaissance plane, the magazine Archaeology reports, spectacular discoveries of ancient shipwrecked vessels were made. Near Marseille the remains of six Roman ships dating to the first and second centuries B.C. were found, along with the wreck of a rare Etruscan ship near Toulon.
Perhaps astronomers will discover asteroid B-612 one day soon.
